title: Psychogenic Tinnitus and Dizziness
chief_complaint: I am having difficulty understanding conversations with my family and at work. I recently 'got into trouble' at work because my voice was too loud on the phone, but I can't tell how loud I am being. I also have constant ringing in my ears, dizziness, and my body feels like it is being squeezed.

problem_summary.onset: Long-standing tinnitus; recent exacerbation of dizziness and sound sensitivity.
problem_summary.course: Worsening symptoms, particularly following a recent traumatic event involving her daughter.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus; hearing loss reported worse in left ear.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Nausea, dizziness, sound sensitivity (hyperacusis), foot pain, cold feet, sensation of body being squeezed, word retrieval issues, memory issues, diplopia.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty at work (crisis intervention specialist), trouble with conversations, inability to tolerate loud sounds.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking help for hearing difficulties and tinnitus, though presentation is complicated by severe anxiety.

history.present_illness: Patient self-referred for hearing evaluation. Reports difficulty maintaining appropriate vocal volume and understanding speech in noise. Reports severe, constant tinnitus causing nausea/dizziness.
history.noise_exposure_history: Reports sound sensitivity to static and loud noises.
history.medical_psych_history: Reports foot pain, cold feet, and body sensation of being 'squeezed'.
history.prior_management: None reported prior to this visit.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear Type A. Right ear could not be tested (CNT) due to aural discomfort.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Could not be obtained due to patient concern regarding anticipated sound levels.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild-to-moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. Low frequencies (250-1000 Hz) are within normal limits to mild loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs in good agreement with PTAs. Good word recognition scores in quiet.

history.present_illness: Patient returned visibly shaken and distracted. Revealed a traumatic event days prior where her daughter attempted to stab her. Reports hearing loss played a role in safety risk.
history.otologic_history: Severe sensitivity to loud sounds; tinnitus exacerbated by stress/anxiety.
history.medical_psych_history: Seeing a behavioral therapist. Taking OTC anxiety meds.

tests.name: High-frequency audiometry
tests.key_findings: Moderate to moderately-severe hearing loss bilaterally from 9,000 to 20,000 Hz.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDL)
tests.key_findings: Severely reduced loudness tolerance levels for both speech and pure tones.

tests.name: Tinnitus Evaluation
tests.key_findings: Could not be completed as patient could not tolerate testing procedures. Declined questionnaires.

history.present_illness: Increasing difficulty with balance. Symptomatic turning head and getting out of bed. Needs support to walk. Diplopia reported 1 week prior.
history.otologic_history: Dizziness, bilateral otalgia, tinnitus, intermittent vertigo.
history.medical_psych_history: Numerous falls, headaches, anxiety/depression, numbness/tingling in leg/foot. Taking Nature-throid, B12, Vit D, Fish Oil, Magnesium, Zinc, Biotin.

tests.name: vHIT
tests.key_findings: Revealed responses but had to be aborted because patient became quickly nauseous.

history.present_illness: Patient presented for hearing aid fitting.
history.otologic_history: Patient had been doing desensitization exercises but misunderstood instructions, playing music 'very loudly' for weeks.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDL)
tests.key_findings: Repeated measures found to be within normal limits, significantly improved from V2.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Confirmed mild sloping to moderate high-frequency SNHL.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild-to-moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. Initial evaluation was complicated by significant anxiety, resulting in incomplete immittance and reflex testing. A subsequent tinnitus evaluation revealed severely reduced loudness discomfort levels (65-75 dB HL), indicative of hyperacusis, though these normalized (90-110 dB HL) by the time of the hearing aid fitting following desensitization efforts. Vestibular assessment was largely inconclusive due to patient nausea and anxiety.
counseling_points: Explain that anxiety and stress can significantly exacerbate tinnitus, dizziness, and sound sensitivity.
Discuss the 'chaos narrative' and help the patient focus on concrete steps for management.
Clarify the correct method for desensitization exercises (start soft, not loud) to avoid further discomfort.
Recommend a multidisciplinary approach, including psychology/psychiatry and neurology, to address the complex interplay of trauma, anxiety, and physical symptoms.
notes_for_actor: Portray a 'chaos narrative': speak in disjointed, poorly organized phrases.
Exhibit high levels of anxiety, distraction, and vagueness when answering direct questions.
During the second visit (Tinnitus Eval), appear visibly shaken and reveal the trauma regarding your daughter.
Complain of a wide range of symptoms (foot pain, cold feet, squeezing sensation) that seem unrelated to hearing.
Become easily nauseous or dizzy during testing procedures.
